In the event of any legal disputes or federal actions that significantly modify the structure or execution of the program, the resolution will still depend on the enrollment figures of the original program or its closest equivalent.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) Apple Inc. resolves a major workers' strike and (b) Virginia's Medicaid plan with work requirements enrolls fewer than 25,000 beneficiaries?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024:

(a) Apple Inc. reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike. For the resolution to be considered valid:
   1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Apple Inc. workers (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Apple Inc. and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the condition is not met.

(b) Virginia's Medicaid plan, which includes a work requirement, enrolls fewer than 25,000 low-income residents. Enrollment figures must be confirmed by official state reports, the Virginia Department of Medical Assistance Services, or at least three widely recognized news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The plan must maintain its work requirement feature throughout the period. If the enrollment is at least 25,000 by the resolution date, and the work requirement is not removed from the plan, the condition is not met. In case of any legal challenges or federal interventions that significantly alter the plan's structure or implementation, the question will still resolve based on the enrollment numbers of the original plan or its closest equivalent.

Only if both (a) and (b) occur as described will the question resolve as YES. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur by July 2024: (a) Apple Inc. resolves a major workers' strike nor (b) Virginia's Medicaid plan with work requirements enrolls fewer than 25,000 beneficiaries?
not_P.body:
This question resolves as YES if neither of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024:

(a) Apple Inc. reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike. For the resolution to be considered valid:
   1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Apple Inc. workers (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Apple Inc. and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If such a resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if a significant strike occurs, the condition is met.

(b) Virginia's Medicaid plan, which includes a work requirement, enrolls fewer than 25,000 low-income residents. Enrollment figures must be confirmed by official state reports, the Virginia Department of Medical Assistance Services, or at least three widely recognized news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The plan must maintain its work requirement feature throughout the period. If the enrollment is at least 25,000 by the resolution date, and the work requirement is not removed from the plan, the condition is met. In case of any legal challenges or federal interventions that significantly alter the plan's structure or implementation, the question will still resolve based on the enrollment numbers of the original plan or its closest equivalent.

Only if neither (a) nor (b) occur as described will the question resolve as YES. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will the following two events take place: (a) Apple Inc. successfully concludes a significant workers' strike and (b) Virginia's Medicaid program with work requirements has fewer than 25,000 enrollees?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with YES if both of the subsequent criteria are fulfilled by July 31, 2024:

(a) Apple Inc. comes to a settlement with its unionized workforce, leading to the conclusion of a major strike. For this resolution to be deemed valid:
   1. The strike must involve a considerable number of Apple Inc. employees (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must persist for a minimum of one week.
   3. The resolution must be verified by official announcements from both Apple Inc. and the relevant union.
   4. The resolution must be covered by at least two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).
   If no resolution satisfying all these criteria is reached by the deadline, or if no significant strike occurs, this condition will not be satisfied.

(b) Virginia's Medicaid program, which incorporates a work requirement, registers fewer than 25,000 low-income participants. Enrollment statistics must be validated by official state documents, the Virginia Department of Medical Assistance Services, or at least three highly regarded news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or leading national newspapers). The work requirement aspect of the plan must remain intact throughout this period. If enrollment reaches 25,000 or more by the specified resolution date, and the work requirement is not eliminated from the program, this condition will not be satisfied. In the event of any legal disputes or federal actions that significantly modify the structure or execution of the plan, the question will still resolve based on the enrollment figures of the original plan or its nearest equivalent.

The question will only resolve as YES if both (a) and (b) occur as outlined. If not, it will resolve as NO.

The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC). question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) the Bank of Canada announce an interest rate cut by August 2024, and (b) Michigan keep the work requirement in its Medicaid plan past July 2024?
question.body:
(a) This part resolves as YES if the Bank of Canada officially announces an interest rate cut to take effect by August 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed by official Bank of Canada communications, such as press releases, Governing Council statements, or public speeches by Bank officials. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, this part resolves as NO. Note that the actual implementation date of the rate cut can be after August 31, 2024, as long as the announcement itself occurs by that date. The interest rate in question refers to the overnight rate, which is the Bank of Canada's primary tool for monetary policy.

(b) This part resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the state of Michigan does not officially announce the removal of the work requirement from its Medicaid plan. If the work requirement remains in place or if no official state announcements or reports by at least two major news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers) confirm its removal, this part resolves as YES. question.title: Will Pedro Sánchez remain the Prime Minister of Spain through July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if Pedro Sánchez continues to hold the position of Prime Minister of Spain through July 31, 2024. Confirmation must come from official Spanish government records or credible news reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., El País, El Mundo, Reuters, AFP). The question will resolve as NO if Sánchez leaves or is removed from the position at any point before or during July 2024. For the purpose of this question, temporary absences due to illness or vacation do not count as leaving the position.

not_P.title: Will Pedro Sánchez not remain the Prime Minister of Spain through July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if Pedro Sánchez does not continue to hold the position of Prime Minister of Spain through July 31, 2024. Confirmation must come from official Spanish government records or credible news reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., El País, El Mundo, Reuters, AFP). The question will resolve as NO if Sánchez continues to hold the position at any point before or during July 2024. For the purpose of this question, temporary absences due to illness or vacation do not count as leaving the position.

para_P.title: Will Pedro Sánchez still be the Prime Minister of Spain by the end of July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if Pedro Sánchez remains in the role of Prime Minister of Spain until July 31, 2024. Verification must be sourced from official Spanish government documentation or reliable news articles from at least two prominent news outlets (e.g., El País, El Mundo, Reuters, AFP). The response will be NO if Sánchez departs or is ousted from the role at any time prior to or during July 2024. For the purposes of this inquiry, temporary leaves due to health issues or holidays do not count as vacating the position.

question.title: Will Boris Johnson remain the Prime Minister of the UK through July 2024 and will Pedro Sánchez leave the position of Prime Minister of Spain by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Boris Johnson continues to hold the position of Prime Minister of the UK through July 31, 2024. Confirmation must come from official UK government records or credible news reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, AFP). Temporary absences due to illness or vacation do not count as leaving the position. (2) Pedro Sánchez leaves or is removed from the position of Prime Minister of Spain at any point before or during July 2024. Confirmation must come from official Spanish government records or credible news reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., El País, El Mundo, Reuters, AFP). Temporary absences due to illness or vacation do not count as leaving the position. The question will resolve as NO if either Boris Johnson does not remain the Prime Minister of the UK through July 2024 or Pedro Sánchez does not leave the position of Prime Minister of Spain by July 2024.

not_P.title: Will Boris Johnson not remain the Prime Minister of the UK through July 2024 or will Pedro Sánchez not leave the position of Prime Minister of Spain by July 2024?

Confirmation must come from official UK government records or credible news reports from at least two major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, AFP). Temporary absences due to illness or vacation do not count as remaining in the position. (2) Pedro Sánchez does not leave or is not removed from the position of Prime Minister of Spain at any point before or during July 2024. The question will resolve as NO if both Boris Johnson remains the Prime Minister of the UK through July 2024 and Pedro Sánchez leaves the position of Prime Minister of Spain by July 2024.

para_P.title: Is it possible for Boris Johnson to still be the Prime Minister of the UK by the end of July 2024 while Pedro Sánchez exits the role of Prime Minister of Spain before that date?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude as YES if both of the following criteria are fulfilled: (1) Boris Johnson persists in his role as Prime Minister of the UK until July 31, 2024. Verification must be obtained from official UK government documentation or reliable news sources from at least two prominent news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, AFP). The inquiry will conclude as NO if either Boris Johnson does not maintain his position as Prime Minister of the UK through July 2024, or Pedro Sánchez does not vacate his role as Prime Minister of Spain by July 2024.

question.title: Will Louisiana's near-total abortion ban be declared constitutional by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a court ruling confirms the constitutionality of Louisiana's near-total abortion ban. The confirmation must come from a Louisiana state court and be reported by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major US newspapers). If the ban is not declared constitutional by the specified date, or if a court rules it unconstitutional, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, a 'near-total abortion ban' refers to the law that was blocked and is pending assessment, as mentioned in the article dated October 1, 2023.

not_P.title: Will Louisiana's near-total abortion ban not be declared constitutional by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a court ruling confirms that Louisiana's near-total abortion ban is unconstitutional. The confirmation must come from a Louisiana state court and be reported by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major US newspapers). If the ban is declared constitutional by the specified date, or if a court rules it constitutional, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, a 'near-total abortion ban' refers to the law that was blocked and is pending assessment, as mentioned in the article dated October 1, 2023.

para_P.title: By August 2024, will a court affirm the constitutionality of Louisiana's near-total abortion prohibition?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by August 31, 2024, a judicial decision verifies the constitutionality of Louisiana's near-total abortion prohibition. The verification must originate from a Louisiana state court and be reported by at least two credible national news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or prominent US newspapers). If the prohibition is not affirmed as constitutional by the given date, or if a court determines it to be unconstitutional, the inquiry will be answered with NO. For the context of this inquiry, a 'near-total abortion prohibition' pertains to the law that was halted and is awaiting evaluation, as referenced in the article dated October 1, 2023.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by August 2024: (1) Missouri conducts a referendum on abortion rights and (2) Louisiana's near-total abortion ban is not declared constitutional?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by August 31, 2024:

1. Missouri conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For this to resolve as YES:
   - The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of Missouri.
   - The primary focus of the referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
   - The referendum results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.
   If no such referendum occurs by the specified date, this part resolves as NO.

2. Louisiana's near-total abortion ban is not declared constitutional. This resolves as YES if:
   - No court ruling confirms the constitutionality of the ban by the specified date.
   - There is no confirmation of constitutionality reported by at least two reputable national news sources.
   If the ban is declared unconstitutional, or if there is no confirmation of constitutionality, this part resolves as YES; otherwise, it resolves as NO.

Both conditions must be met for the overall question to resolve as YES. If either condition is not met, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur by August 2024: (1) Missouri conducts a referendum on abortion rights nor (2) Louisiana's near-total abortion ban is declared constitutional?
not_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if neither of the following conditions are met by August 31, 2024:

1. Missouri conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For this to resolve as YES:
   - The referendum must not be officially announced and conducted by the state of Missouri.
   - The primary focus of the referendum must not be on abortion rights protection.
   - The referendum results must not be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.
   If such a referendum occurs by the specified date, this part resolves as NO.

2. Louisiana's near-total abortion ban is declared constitutional. This resolves as YES if:
   - A court ruling confirms the constitutionality of the ban by the specified date.
   - There is confirmation of constitutionality reported by at least two reputable national news sources.
   If the ban is not declared constitutional, or if there is no confirmation of constitutionality, this part resolves as NO; otherwise, it resolves as YES.

Neither condition must be met for the overall question to resolve as YES. If either condition is met, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: By August 2024, will the following two events take place: (1) A public vote on abortion rights happens in Missouri and (2) Louisiana's near-total ban on abortion remains unconstitutionally challenged?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with YES if both of the following criteria are fulfilled by August 31, 2024:

1. Missouri holds a public vote aimed at establishing protections for abortion rights within the state. To resolve this as YES:
   - The vote must be officially announced and carried out by the state of Missouri.
   - The main focus of the vote must be on safeguarding abortion rights.
   - The results of the vote must be publicly disclosed by official state channels or widely acknowledged news outlets.
   If such a vote does not take place by the designated date, this part will resolve as NO.

2. Louisiana's near-total abortion prohibition is not affirmed as constitutional. This will resolve as YES if:
   - No judicial decision upholds the constitutionality of the prohibition by the specified date.
   - There is no affirmation of constitutionality reported by at least two credible national news organizations.
   If the prohibition is declared unconstitutional, or if there is no affirmation of constitutionality, this part resolves as YES; otherwise, it resolves as NO.

Both criteria must be satisfied for the overall inquiry to resolve as YES. If either criterion is not satisfied, the inquiry resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The Central Bank of Mexico announces an interest rate cut by July 2024, and (b) The Central Bank of South Korea does not announce a new digital payment system by August 2024?
question.body:
(a) The Central Bank of Mexico must officially announce a decrease in its target for the overnight interbank interest rate by July 31, 2024. This announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Central Bank of Mexico or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Board of Governors and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual Central Bank of Mexico members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, this part resolves as NO.

(b) The Central Bank of South Korea must not officially announce the launch of a new digital payment system by August 31, 2024. If no announcement is made from an official Central Bank of South Korea communication channel, such as a press release or a public speech by the Governor of the Central Bank of South Korea, explicitly stating the introduction of the digital payment system, or if the announcement is not reported by at least two major financial news outlets (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC, Financial Times), then this part resolves as YES. The combined question resolves as YES if both (a) the Central Bank of Mexico announces the interest rate cut by the specified date and (b) the Central Bank of South Korea does not announce the new digital payment system by the specified date. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.

question.title: Will China's central bank's preferred inflation measure show a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if China's central bank's preferred inflation measure reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. question.title: Will Nigeria's Senate pass a major economic reform bill opposed by President Tinubu by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Nigeria's Senate passes a major economic reform bill that is explicitly opposed by President Bola Tinubu or his administration. To qualify:

1. The bill must be related to economic policy, such as fiscal spending, taxation, or monetary policy.
2. It must be passed by the Senate, regardless of whether it becomes law.
3. The opposition from President Tinubu or his administration must be clearly reported by at least two major international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, Financial Times).
4. The bill must be described as 'major' or 'significant' by these news sources in terms of its potential impact on the Nigerian economy.

If no such bill is passed by the Senate by August 31, 2024, or if a bill is passed but does not meet all the above criteria, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Bayer allows generic production of its cardiovascular drug by July 2024, and (b) Nigeria's Senate fails to pass a major economic reform bill opposed by President Tinubu by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) By July 31, 2024, Bayer officially announces or confirms that it will allow generic production of its cardiovascular drug, effectively not enforcing its patent. This could be through a formal patent withdrawal, a voluntary license agreement, or any other mechanism that allows for unrestricted generic production. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, statements from relevant regulatory bodies, or reports by at least two reputable international news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or major national newspapers). If no such announcement or confirmation is made by the specified date, or if Bayer continues to enforce its patent rights, this part resolves as NO.

(b) By August 31, 2024, Nigeria's Senate does not pass a major economic reform bill that is explicitly opposed by President Bola Tinubu or his administration. To qualify:
1. No bill related to economic policy, such as fiscal spending, taxation, or monetary policy, is passed by the Senate.
2. Or, if a bill is passed by the Senate, it is not opposed by President Tinubu or his administration as clearly reported by at least two major international news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, Financial Times).
3. Or, the bill is not described as 'major' or 'significant' by these news sources in terms of its potential impact on the Nigerian economy.
If no such bill is passed by the Senate by August 31, 2024, or if a bill is passed but does not meet all the above criteria, this part resolves as YES.

The overall question resolves as YES only if both (a) and (b) resolve as YES.

question.title: Will TikTok's AI-driven content recommendations be reported for spreading election misinformation by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, there are credible reports or official warnings from election officials, government authorities, or reputable news organizations stating that TikTok's AI-driven content recommendations are spreading election misinformation. For the purpose of this question, 'election misinformation' refers to false or misleading information about election processes, candidates, or results. Credible reports should come from at least two of the following sources: state or federal election officials, major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, or major US networks), or peer-reviewed studies published in reputable journals. The reports or warnings must specifically mention TikTok's AI and its role in spreading election misinformation. question.title: Will Colorado's near-total abortion ban be declared constitutional by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a court ruling confirms the constitutionality of Colorado's near-total abortion ban. The confirmation must come from a Colorado state court and be reported by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major US newspapers). If the ban is not declared constitutional by the specified date, or if a court rules it unconstitutional, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, a 'near-total abortion ban' refers to the law that was blocked and is pending assessment, as mentioned in the article dated October 1, 2023.

If the law is repealed or significantly altered by the specified date, this part resolves as NO. (b) No court ruling confirms the constitutionality of Colorado's near-total abortion ban. For the purpose of this part, a 'near-total abortion ban' refers to the law that was blocked and is pending assessment, as mentioned in the article dated October 1, 2023. question.title: Will Spain eliminate export taxes on agricultural products by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Spanish government officially announces or implements a policy to completely eliminate export taxes on agricultural products. The policy must be confirmed by official government communications or reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or Associated Press). Partial reductions in export taxes or the elimination of taxes on only some agricultural products will not be sufficient for a YES resolution. If no such policy is introduced or implemented by the resolution date, or if only partial measures are taken, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will Spain not eliminate export taxes on agricultural products by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Spanish government does not officially announce or implement a policy to completely eliminate export taxes on agricultural products. The policy must not be confirmed by official government communications or reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or Associated Press). Any partial reductions in export taxes or the elimination of taxes on only some agricultural products will be sufficient for a YES resolution. If such a policy is introduced or implemented by the resolution date, or if only partial measures are taken, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will Spain remove export duties on agricultural goods by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed TRUE if, by July 31, 2024, the Spanish authorities officially declare or put into effect a policy to entirely abolish export duties on agricultural goods. The policy must be validated by official government announcements or covered by at least two credible international news organizations (like Reuters, Bloomberg, or Associated Press). Any partial cuts in export duties or the removal of duties on only certain agricultural goods will not suffice for a TRUE resolution. If no such policy is enacted or introduced by the resolution date, or if only partial actions are taken, the inquiry will resolve as FALSE.

question.title: Will the United States report a bumper harvest for both corn and soybeans by August 2024 and will Spain maintain export taxes on some or all agricultural products beyond July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) By August 31, 2024, the United States officially reports a bumper harvest for both corn and soybeans, indicating higher than average yields compared to the previous five-year average. A bumper harvest is defined as a crop yield that is significantly above average, typically at least 10% higher than the five-year average. Confirmation must come from official reports by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) or at least three reputable news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or The Wall Street Journal). If a bumper harvest is reported for only one of the crops (either corn or soybeans) but not both, or if no bumper harvest is reported for either crop, this part resolves as NO. (b) By July 31, 2024, the Spanish government does not officially announce or implement a policy to completely eliminate export taxes on agricultural products. If no such policy is introduced or implemented by the resolution date, or if only partial measures are taken, this part resolves as YES. The policy must be confirmed by official government communications or reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or Associated Press). Partial reductions in export taxes or the elimination of taxes on only some agricultural products will be sufficient for a YES resolution. The overall question resolves as YES only if both conditions (a) and (b) are satisfied.

not_P.title: Will the United States not report a bumper harvest for both corn and soybeans by August 2024 or will Spain completely eliminate export taxes on some or all agricultural products by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if at least one of the following conditions is met: (a) By August 31, 2024, the United States does not officially report a bumper harvest for both corn and soybeans, indicating that the yields are not significantly above average compared to the previous five-year average. Complete elimination of export taxes on all agricultural products will be sufficient for a NO resolution. The overall question resolves as YES if at least one of the conditions (a) or (b) is satisfied.

para_P.title: By August 2024, will the United States announce a record harvest for both corn and soybeans, and will Spain continue to impose export taxes on certain or all agricultural goods beyond July 2024?

question.title: Will Missouri hold a referendum on abortion rights by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Missouri officially conducts a statewide referendum specifically on the topic of enshrining abortion rights in the state constitution. The referendum must be formally announced by the Missouri state government and verified by at least two major news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, NPR, or major Missouri-based news outlets). The referendum must be open to all eligible voters in Missouri and focus primarily on abortion rights. If no such referendum occurs or is completed by the resolution date, or if the referendum is canceled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Note that this question only pertains to the occurrence of the referendum, not its outcome.

question.title: Will the World Health Organization declare the current West Nile virus outbreak over by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares the ongoing West Nile virus outbreak over by August 31, 2024. The declaration must be confirmed through official WHO announcements or reports from at least three reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC). The outbreak referred to in this question is the one that prompted heightened public health responses globally. If no such declaration ending the outbreak is made by the resolution date, or if the WHO extends the emergency status beyond August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will the World Health Organization not declare the current West Nile virus outbreak over by August 2024?

The outbreak referred to in this question is the one that prompted heightened public health responses globally. question.title: Will both of the following occur by August 2024: (a) Land O'Frost issues a recall of deli meats due to a listeria outbreak and (b) the WHO does not declare the current West Nile virus outbreak over?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met by August 31, 2024:

(a) Land O'Frost officially announces a recall of any of its deli meat products due to a listeria outbreak. The recall must be confirmed through at least one of the following sources:
   1. An official announcement on Land O'Frost's website or social media channels
   2. A press release from Land O'Frost
   3. An announcement from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) specifically mentioning a Land O'Frost recall
   4. Reports from at least three major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) citing official sources
   The recall must explicitly mention listeria as the reason for the product withdrawal.

(b) The World Health Organization (WHO) does not officially declare the ongoing West Nile virus outbreak over. This includes scenarios where no declaration is made, or if the WHO extends the emergency status beyond August 31, 2024. The declaration must be confirmed through official WHO announcements or reports from at least three reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC).

If both conditions are met, the question will resolve as YES. If either or both conditions are not met, the question will resolve as NO.

   2. A press release from Land O'Frost
   3. An announcement from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) specifically mentioning a Land O'Frost recall
   4. Reports from at least three major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) citing official sources
   The recall must not explicitly mention listeria as the reason for the product withdrawal.

(b) The World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares the ongoing West Nile virus outbreak over. This includes scenarios where a declaration is made, or if the WHO does not extend the emergency status beyond August 31, 2024. The declaration must be confirmed through official WHO announcements or reports from fewer than three reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC).

If neither condition is met, the question will resolve as YES. If either or both conditions are met, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Is it true that by August 2024, both (a) Land O'Frost will have to recall deli meats due to a listeria outbreak and (b) the WHO will not have declared the current West Nile virus outbreak as resolved?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be answered with a YES if both of the following criteria are satisfied by August 31, 2024:

(a) Land O'Frost makes a formal statement regarding a recall of any of its deli meat items because of a listeria outbreak. This recall must be verified through at least one of the following channels:
   1. An official communication on Land O'Frost's website or social media platforms
   2. A press release issued by Land O'Frost
   3. An announcement from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) that specifically refers to a Land O'Frost recall
   4. Reports from a minimum of three major news organizations (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) citing official sources
   The recall must clearly state listeria as the cause for the withdrawal of the products.

(b) The World Health Organization (WHO) does not make an official statement declaring the ongoing West Nile virus outbreak as concluded. This encompasses situations where no declaration is issued, or if the WHO prolongs the emergency status past August 31, 2024. The declaration must be substantiated through official WHO communications or reports from at least three credible news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC).

If both conditions are fulfilled, the inquiry will be resolved as YES. If either or both conditions are unmet, the inquiry will be resolved as NO.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by August 2024: (a) the WHO declares the current West Nile virus outbreak over, or (b) Land O'Frost issues a recall of deli meats due to a listeria outbreak?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if either of the following events occurs by August 31, 2024:

(a) The World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares the ongoing West Nile virus outbreak over. This declaration must be confirmed through official WHO announcements or reports from at least three reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC). The outbreak referred to is the one that prompted heightened public health responses globally. If no such declaration ending the outbreak is made by the resolution date, or if the WHO extends the emergency status beyond August 31, 2024, this part will resolve as NO.

(b) Land O'Frost officially announces a recall of any of its deli meat products due to a listeria outbreak. The recall must be confirmed through at least one of the following sources: an official announcement on Land O'Frost's website or social media channels, a press release from Land O'Frost, an announcement from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) specifically mentioning a Land O'Frost recall, or reports from at least three major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) citing official sources. The recall must explicitly mention listeria as the reason for the product withdrawal. If no such recall meeting these criteria is announced by the specified date, this part will resolve as NO.

If either (a) or (b) occurs, the question will resolve as YES.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur by August 2024: (a) the WHO declares the current West Nile virus outbreak over, nor (b) Land O'Frost issues a recall of deli meats due to a listeria outbreak?
not_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if neither of the following events occurs by August 31, 2024:

(a) The World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares the ongoing West Nile virus outbreak over. This declaration must not be confirmed through official WHO announcements or reports from at least three reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC). If such a declaration ending the outbreak is made by the resolution date, or if the WHO does not extend the emergency status beyond August 31, 2024, this part will resolve as YES.

(b) Land O'Frost officially announces a recall of any of its deli meat products due to a listeria outbreak. The recall must not be confirmed through at least one of the following sources: an official announcement on Land O'Frost's website or social media channels, a press release from Land O'Frost, an announcement from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) specifically mentioning a Land O'Frost recall, or reports from at least three major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) citing official sources. The recall must not explicitly mention listeria as the reason for the product withdrawal. If such a recall meeting these criteria is announced by the specified date, this part will resolve as YES.

If neither (a) nor (b) occurs, the question will resolve as YES.

para_P.title: Is there a possibility that by August 2024, either the WHO will announce the conclusion of the current West Nile virus outbreak, or Land O'Frost will recall deli meats due to a listeria outbreak?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be considered TRUE if at least one of the following events takes place by August 31, 2024:

(a) The World Health Organization (WHO) officially states that the ongoing West Nile virus outbreak has ended. This statement must be verified through official announcements from the WHO or reports from a minimum of three credible news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, or BBC). The outbreak in question is the one that led to increased global public health measures. If there is no such announcement declaring the end of the outbreak by the resolution date, or if the WHO prolongs the emergency situation beyond August 31, 2024, this segment will resolve as FALSE.

(b) Land O'Frost makes a formal announcement regarding a recall of any of its deli meat products due to a listeria outbreak. This recall must be substantiated by at least one of the following sources: an official statement on Land O'Frost's website or social media platforms, a press release from Land O'Frost, a notice from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) specifically addressing a Land O'Frost recall, or reports from at least three major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, CNN, New York Times) citing authoritative sources. The recall must clearly state listeria as the reason for the withdrawal of the products. If no recall that meets these requirements is announced by the designated date, this part will resolve as FALSE.

If either (a) or (b) takes place, the inquiry will resolve as TRUE.

question.title: Will the average rate on a 15-year mortgage in the US fall below 5.0% by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage in the United States, as reported by Freddie Mac in their Primary Mortgage Market Survey, falls below 5.0% at any point. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or at least two reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC. If the rate does not fall below 5.0% by the specified date, or if Freddie Mac discontinues reporting this metric, the question will resolve as NO. For clarity, a rate of exactly 5.0% will not be considered as falling below 5.0%.

not_P.title: Will the average rate on a 15-year mortgage in the US not fall below 5.0% by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage in the United States, as reported by Freddie Mac in their Primary Mortgage Market Survey, does not fall below 5.0% at any point. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or at least two reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC. If the rate falls below 5.0% by the specified date, or if Freddie Mac discontinues reporting this metric, the question will resolve as NO. For clarity, a rate of exactly 5.0% will be considered as not falling below 5.0%.

para_P.title: Is it possible for the average interest rate on a 15-year mortgage in the United States to drop under 5.0% by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed TRUE if, by August 31, 2024, the average interest rate on a 15-year fixed mortgage in the US, as indicated by Freddie Mac in their Primary Mortgage Market Survey, dips below 5.0% at any time. The rate must be validated by official documentation from Freddie Mac or at least two credible financial news outlets such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC. If the rate does not go below 5.0% by the given date, or if Freddie Mac stops providing this information, the inquiry will be considered FALSE. For clarification, a rate of exactly 5.0% will not be regarded as falling below 5.0%.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Jerome Powell remains as Federal Reserve Chair through July 2024, and (2) the average rate on a 15-year mortgage in the US does not fall below 5.0% by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Jerome Powell is still serving as the Chair of the Federal Reserve on July 31, 2024. Confirmation must come from official Federal Reserve announcements or be reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, CNBC, The Wall Street Journal, or Bloomberg). If he is no longer serving as Chair by the resolution date for any reason (including but not limited to resignation, removal, or end of term), the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, any interim or acting Chair appointments will not be considered as Powell remaining in the position. (2) By August 31, 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage in the United States, as reported by Freddie Mac in their Primary Mortgage Market Survey, does not fall below 5.0% at any point. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or the absence of reports from at least two reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC indicating a drop below 5.0%. If the rate falls below 5.0% by the specified date, the question will resolve as NO. For clarity, a rate of exactly 5.0% will be considered as not falling below 5.0%.

not_P.title: Will either of the following not occur: (1) Jerome Powell does not remain as Federal Reserve Chair through July 2024, or (2) the average rate on a 15-year mortgage in the US falls below 5.0% by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if either of the following conditions are met: (1) Jerome Powell is no longer serving as the Chair of the Federal Reserve on July 31, 2024. Confirmation must come from official Federal Reserve announcements or be reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, CNBC, The Wall Street Journal, or Bloomberg). If he is still serving as Chair by the resolution date for any reason (including but not limited to resignation, removal, or end of term), the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, any interim or acting Chair appointments will not be considered as Powell remaining in the position. (2) By August 31, 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage in the United States, as reported by Freddie Mac in their Primary Mortgage Market Survey, falls below 5.0% at any point. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or the presence of reports from at least two reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC indicating a drop below 5.0%. If the rate does not fall below 5.0% by the specified date, the question will resolve as NO. For clarity, a rate of exactly 5.0% will be considered as falling below 5.0%.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will take place: (1) Jerome Powell continues his role as Federal Reserve Chair until July 2024, and (2) the average interest rate on a 15-year mortgage in the US stays at or above 5.0% until August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if the following two criteria are satisfied: (1) Jerome Powell is still in the position of Chair of the Federal Reserve on July 31, 2024. question.title: Will either of the following occur by their respective dates: (a) the average rate on a 15-year mortgage in the US falls below 5.0% by August 2024, or (b) Jerome Powell remains as Federal Reserve Chair through July 2024?

This question will resolve as YES if either of the following conditions is met:

Interim or acting Chair appointments will not be considered as Powell remaining in the position.

If neither condition is met, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Is it possible that by their specified deadlines, either (a) the average interest rate on a 15-year mortgage in the US drops below 5.0% before August 2024, or (b) Jerome Powell continues to serve as the Chair of the Federal Reserve until July 2024?

(b) Jerome Powell remains in his role as the Chair of the Federal Reserve on July 31, 2024. Verification must be provided through official announcements from the Federal Reserve or reported by at least two major news organizations (such as Reuters, CNBC, The Wall Street Journal, or Bloomberg). If he is no longer in the position by the resolution date for any reason (including but not limited to resignation, removal, or end of term), the question will be answered as NO. Interim or acting Chair appointments will not count as Powell still being in the position.

If neither scenario occurs, the question will be answered as NO.

question.title: Will Iowa's 6-week abortion ban be overturned by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Iowa's law banning most abortions after approximately six weeks of pregnancy is either repealed by the state legislature or invalidated by a court ruling. The repeal or invalidation must be confirmed by official state announcements or reported by at least two reputable news sources. If the law remains in effect as of July 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'overturned' means the law is no longer enforceable in its current form, either through legislative action or judicial decision.

not_P.title: Will Iowa's 6-week abortion ban not be overturned by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, Iowa's law banning most abortions after approximately six weeks of pregnancy is neither repealed by the state legislature nor invalidated by a court ruling. The repeal or invalidation must not be confirmed by official state announcements or reported by at least two reputable news sources. If the law remains in effect as of July 31, 2024, the question resolves as YES. For the purpose of this question, 'not overturned' means the law is still enforceable in its current form, either through legislative action or judicial decision.

para_P.title: Will the 6-week abortion restriction in Iowa be rescinded by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, the law in Iowa that prohibits most abortions after roughly six weeks of gestation is either annulled by the state legislature or rendered void by a judicial ruling. The annulment or voiding must be substantiated by official state announcements or reported by at least two credible news outlets. If the law is still in effect as of July 31, 2024, the inquiry will be answered with a NO. For the purposes of this inquiry, 'rescinded' indicates that the law is no longer enforceable in its present form, whether through legislative measures or court decisions.

question.title: Will both Colorado's abortion law allowing procedures up to 22 weeks remain unchanged by August 2024 and Iowa's 6-week abortion ban remain in effect through July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if both of the following occur: (1) By August 31, 2024, Colorado's current abortion law permitting abortions up to 22 weeks remains in effect without any changes. The status of the law must be confirmed by official state legislative records or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or local Colorado newspapers). If the law is modified, replaced, or overturned by the specified date, the question resolves as NO. This includes any changes that either restrict or expand the current 22-week limit. (2) By July 31, 2024, Iowa's law banning most abortions after approximately six weeks of pregnancy remains in effect and is not repealed by the state legislature or invalidated by a court ruling. The continued enforcement of the law must be confirmed by the absence of official state announcements or lack of reports by at least two reputable news sources indicating its repeal or invalidation. If the law is overturned as of July 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'remain in effect' means the law is still enforceable in its current form, with no legislative action or judicial decision rendering it void.

not_P.title: Will either Colorado's abortion law allowing procedures up to 22 weeks be modified, replaced, or overturned by August 2024 or Iowa's 6-week abortion ban be repealed or invalidated through July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if either of the following occur: (1) By August 31, 2024, Colorado's current abortion law permitting abortions up to 22 weeks is modified, replaced, or overturned. The status of the law must be confirmed by official state legislative records or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or local Colorado newspapers). If the law remains unchanged by the specified date, the question resolves as NO. This includes any changes that either restrict or expand the current 22-week limit. (2) By July 31, 2024, Iowa's law banning most abortions after approximately six weeks of pregnancy is repealed by the state legislature or invalidated by a court ruling. The continued enforcement of the law must be confirmed by the presence of official state announcements or reports by at least two reputable news sources indicating its repeal or invalidation. If the law remains in effect as of July 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'be repealed or invalidated' means the law is no longer enforceable in its current form, with legislative action or judicial decision rendering it void.

para_P.title: Will Colorado's abortion legislation that permits procedures up to 22 weeks stay the same by August 2024, and will Iowa's 6-week abortion prohibition continue to be in force until July 2024?
para_P.body: This question is answered with YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) By August 31, 2024, Colorado's existing abortion legislation that allows for abortions up to 22 weeks is still in place without any modifications. The law's status must be verified by official state legislative documentation or reported by at least two major news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or local Colorado media). If there are any amendments, replacements, or annulments of the law by the specified date, the answer will be NO. This includes any alterations that either limit or broaden the current 22-week provision. (2) By July 31, 2024, Iowa's legislation prohibiting most abortions after roughly six weeks of pregnancy is still in effect and has not been rescinded by the state legislature or overturned by a court decision. The ongoing enforcement of this law must be confirmed by the absence of official state communications or lack of reports from at least two credible news outlets indicating its repeal or annulment. If the law is nullified as of July 31, 2024, the answer will be NO. For the purposes of this inquiry, 'stay in force' means the law continues to be applicable in its current format, with no legislative or judicial actions rendering it invalid.

question.title: Will either of the following occur by August 2024: (a) Iowa's 6-week abortion ban is overturned by July 2024, or (b) Colorado's abortion law allowing procedures up to 22 weeks is changed by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if either of the following occurs: (a) By July 31, 2024, Iowa's law banning most abortions after approximately six weeks of pregnancy is either repealed by the state legislature or invalidated by a court ruling. The repeal or invalidation must be confirmed by official state announcements or reported by at least two reputable news sources. For this part, 'overturned' means the law is no longer enforceable in its current form, either through legislative action or judicial decision. (b) By August 31, 2024, Colorado's current abortion law permitting abortions up to 22 weeks is modified, replaced, or overturned. This includes any changes that either restrict or expand the current 22-week limit. The status of the law must be confirmed by official state legislative records or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or local Colorado newspapers). If neither event occurs by the specified dates, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur by August 2024: (a) Iowa's 6-week abortion ban is overturned by July 2024, nor (b) Colorado's abortion law allowing procedures up to 22 weeks is changed by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if neither of the following occurs: (a) By July 31, 2024, Iowa's law banning most abortions after approximately six weeks of pregnancy is repealed by the state legislature or invalidated by a court ruling. The repeal or invalidation must be confirmed by official state announcements or reported by at least two reputable news sources. For this part, 'overturned' means the law is no longer enforceable in its current form, either through legislative action or judicial decision. (b) By August 31, 2024, Colorado's current abortion law permitting abortions up to 22 weeks is modified, replaced, or overturned. This includes any changes that either restrict or expand the current 22-week limit. The status of the law must be confirmed by official state legislative records or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or local Colorado newspapers). If either event occurs by the specified dates, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it possible that by August 2024, one of the following will take place: (a) Iowa's six-week abortion restriction is nullified by July 2024, or (b) Colorado's abortion regulations allowing procedures up to 22 weeks are altered by August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry is answered with a YES if at least one of the following happens: (a) By July 31, 2024, Iowa's legislation prohibiting most abortions after roughly six weeks of gestation is either annulled by the state legislature or deemed invalid by a judicial ruling. The annulment or invalidation must be verified through official state announcements or reported by a minimum of two credible news organizations. In this context, 'nullified' indicates that the law is no longer applicable in its existing form, whether through legislative measures or court decisions. (b) By August 31, 2024, Colorado's existing abortion statute allowing abortions up to 22 weeks is amended, replaced, or revoked. This encompasses any modifications that either tighten or loosen the current 22-week limit. The condition of the law must be substantiated by official state legislative documents or reported by at least two prominent news agencies (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or local newspapers from Colorado). If neither occurrence takes place by the specified deadlines, the response will be NO.

question.title: Will another U.S. state adopt a Medicaid plan with a mental health support requirement by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, at least one U.S. state other than Georgia officially adopts a Medicaid plan that includes a mental health support requirement for beneficiaries. The mental health support requirement must be a key component of the plan. For a positive resolution, there must be an official announcement from the state government or the state's Medicaid agency, or consistent reporting from at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Washington Post). The plan must be officially adopted, not merely proposed or under consideration. If no other state adopts such a plan by July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will no other U.S. state adopt a Medicaid plan without a mental health support requirement by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, no U.S. state other than Georgia officially adopts a Medicaid plan that includes a mental health support requirement for beneficiaries. The mental health support requirement must be a key component of the plan. For a positive resolution, there must be no official announcement from the state government or the state's Medicaid agency, or consistent reporting from at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Washington Post). The plan must not be officially adopted, but merely proposed or under consideration. If at least one other state adopts such a plan by July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Is it possible for another U.S. state to implement a Medicaid program that mandates mental health support by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered affirmatively if, by July 31, 2024, at least one U.S. state, excluding Georgia, formally implements a Medicaid program that necessitates mental health support for its beneficiaries. The mental health support requirement must be a fundamental aspect of the program. For an affirmative outcome, there must be an official declaration from the state's government or Medicaid agency, or consistent coverage from a minimum of two credible national news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Washington Post). The program must be officially enacted, not just suggested or under review. If no other state enacts such a program by July 31, 2024, the inquiry will be answered negatively.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Tennessee conducts a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024, and (b) no other U.S. state adopts a Medicaid plan with a mental health support requirement by July 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur:

(a) By August 31, 2024, Tennessee conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. The criteria for this are:
   1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of Tennessee.
   2. The primary focus of the referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
   3. The referendum results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.
   If no such referendum meeting these criteria occurs by August 31, 2024, this part will resolve as NO.

(b) By July 31, 2024, no U.S. state other than Georgia officially adopts a Medicaid plan that includes a mental health support requirement for beneficiaries. The criteria for this are:
   1. The mental health support requirement must be a key component of the plan.
   2. There must be no official announcement from any state government or state's Medicaid agency, and no consistent reporting from at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Washington Post).
   3. The plan must not be officially adopted, only proposed or under consideration.
   If another state adopts such a plan by July 31, 2024, this part will resolve as NO.

The question will resolve as YES only if both (a) and (b) resolve as YES.

not_P.title: Will at least one of the following occur: (a) Tennessee does not conduct a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024, or (b) at least one other U.S. state adopts a Medicaid plan with a mental health support requirement by July 2024?
not_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if at least one of the following occurs:

(a) By August 31, 2024, Tennessee does not conduct a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. The criteria for this are:
   1. The referendum must not be officially announced and conducted by the state of Tennessee.
   2. The primary focus of the referendum must not be on abortion rights protection.
   3. The referendum results must not be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.
   If such a referendum meeting these criteria occurs by August 31, 2024, this part will resolve as NO.

(b) By July 31, 2024, at least one U.S. state other than Georgia officially adopts a Medicaid plan that includes a mental health support requirement for beneficiaries. The criteria for this are:
   1. The mental health support requirement must be a key component of the plan.
   2. There must be an official announcement from a state government or state's Medicaid agency, and consistent reporting from at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Washington Post).
   3. The plan must be officially adopted, not just proposed or under consideration.
   If no other state adopts such a plan by July 31, 2024, this part will resolve as NO.

The question will resolve as YES if at least one of (a) or (b) resolves as YES.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will happen: (a) Tennessee will hold a public vote on abortion rights before August 2024, and (b) no other state in the U.S. will implement a Medicaid plan requiring mental health support by July 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if both of the following conditions are satisfied:

(a) By August 31, 2024, Tennessee carries out a public vote specifically aimed at securing protections for abortion rights within the state. The requirements for this are:
   1. The vote must be formally announced and executed by the state of Tennessee.
   2. The main focus of the vote must be on safeguarding abortion rights.
   3. The outcomes of the vote must be disclosed through official state channels or recognized news outlets.
   If no such vote that meets these requirements occurs by August 31, 2024, this part will be marked as NO.

(b) By July 31, 2024, no U.S. state other than Georgia officially implements a Medicaid plan that includes a requirement for mental health support for its beneficiaries. The stipulations for this are:
   1. The mental health support requirement must be an essential element of the plan.
   2. There must be no official declaration from any state government or Medicaid agency, nor consistent coverage from at least two credible national news organizations (like Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Washington Post).
   3. The plan must not be officially adopted, but merely proposed or under evaluation.

The question will be marked as YES only if both (a) and (b) are marked as YES.

question.title: Will a major social media platform be reported for spreading election misinformation through its AI systems by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, there are credible reports or official warnings from election officials, government authorities, or reputable news organizations stating that a major social media platform is spreading election misinformation through its AI systems. For the purpose of this question, 'election misinformation' refers to false or misleading information about election processes, candidates, or results. Credible reports should come from at least two of the following sources: state or federal election officials, major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, BBC, or major US networks), or peer-reviewed studies published in reputable journals. The reports or warnings must specifically mention the platform and its AI systems' role in spreading election misinformation. If no such reports or warnings are issued by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the Reserve Bank of India announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Reserve Bank of India officially announces a decrease in its repo rate by July 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Reserve Bank of India or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Monetary Policy Committee and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual RBI members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will the Reserve Bank of India not announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Reserve Bank of India does not officially announce a decrease in its repo rate by July 31, 2024. The absence of an announcement must be confirmed through official statements from the Reserve Bank of India or reported by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The lack of an interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Monetary Policy Committee and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual RBI members will not count for resolution. If such an official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if the Reserve Bank of India makes a formal declaration of a reduction in its repo rate by July 31, 2024. The announcement must be validated through official communications from the Reserve Bank of India or covered by at least two prominent financial news outlets (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). The interest rate reduction should be a formal resolution taken by the Monetary Policy Committee and conveyed in their official statement or press briefing after a meeting. Any conjectures regarding potential future rate reductions or informal comments from individual RBI members will not be considered for resolution. If there is no official announcement regarding an interest rate reduction by the resolution date, the inquiry will be resolved as negative.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (1) Oracle announces measures to reduce AI-related electricity consumption, and (2) The Reserve Bank of India does not announce an interest rate cut?

The announcement must be made through official company channels (such as press releases, blog posts, or annual reports) or reported by at least two major news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Bloomberg, Wall Street Journal, New York Times). The measures announced should be concrete steps or initiatives designed to decrease the energy usage of Oracle's AI systems. (2) The Reserve Bank of India does not officially announce a decrease in its repo rate. The absence of such an announcement must be confirmed through the lack of official statements from the Reserve Bank of India or the absence of reports by at least two major financial news sources (such as Bloomberg, Reuters, The Wall Street Journal, or CNBC). If both conditions are met by the specified date, the question resolves as YES. If either condition is not met, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will a major hospital system in the Northeast US cancel over $300 million in medical debt by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a hospital system based in the Northeast United States, in collaboration with a nonprofit organization, successfully cancels more than $300 million in medical debt for at least 150,000 patients across multiple Northeastern states. The cancellation must be officially announced by the hospital system or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The debt cancellation should target patients who are considered financially needy or unable to pay. If the debt cancellation is not completed or officially confirmed by the specified date, or if the amount cancelled is $300 million or less, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Hyundai Motor Company resolves a major workers' strike by July 2024, and (b) no major hospital system in the Northeast US cancels over $300 million in medical debt by August 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) Hyundai Motor Company reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For this condition to be met:
   1. The strike must involve at least 1,000 Hyundai Motor Company workers.
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Hyundai Motor Company and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

(b) By August 31, 2024, no hospital system based in the Northeast United States, in collaboration with a nonprofit organization, successfully cancels more than $300 million in medical debt for at least 150,000 patients across multiple Northeastern states. Alternatively, this condition is met if the cancellation is not officially announced by the hospital system or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The debt cancellation should target patients who are considered financially needy or unable to pay.

If both conditions are met, the question resolves as YES. If either condition is not met, the question resolves as NO.

   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must not be confirmed by official statements from both Hyundai Motor Company and the involved union.

(b) By August 31, 2024, at least one hospital system based in the Northeast United States, in collaboration with a nonprofit organization, successfully cancels more than $300 million in medical debt for at least 150,000 patients across multiple Northeastern states. Alternatively, this condition is met if the cancellation is officially announced by the hospital system or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). The debt cancellation should target patients who are considered financially needy or unable to pay.

If at least one condition is met, the question resolves as YES. If both conditions are met, the question resolves as NO.

question.title: Will Virginia maintain its current legal stance on abortion access by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Virginia Supreme Court has not reversed or significantly altered its 2023 decision that struck down state laws regulating abortion providers more strictly than other health care providers and banned a common second-trimester procedure. The question will resolve as NO if, by July 31, 2024, the Virginia Supreme Court has reversed this decision, reinstated stricter regulations on abortion providers, or reinstated the ban on the second-trimester procedure. The resolution will be based on official court decisions or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, The New York Times, The Washington Post).

question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, either the Virginia Supreme Court or the Florida Supreme Court has not reversed or significantly altered their respective 2023 decisions that struck down state laws regulating abortion providers more strictly than other health care providers and banned a common second-trimester procedure. The question will resolve as NO if, by July 31, 2024, both the Virginia Supreme Court and the Florida Supreme Court have reversed their decisions, reinstated stricter regulations on abortion providers, or reinstated the ban on the second-trimester procedure. The resolution will be based on official court decisions or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., Associated Press, Reuters, The New York Times, The Washington Post).

question.title: Will IBM lay off at least 1,800 employees by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, IBM has confirmed the layoff of at least 1,800 employees as part of its AI-focused reorganization plan. Confirmation must come from official company announcements, regulatory filings, or reports by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The layoffs must be explicitly linked to the AI-focused reorganization plan announced in 2023. If IBM confirms a lower number of layoffs, or if no such confirmation meeting these criteria is made by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO. Partial layoffs or phased implementations that do not reach the 1,800 employee threshold by the resolution date will also result in a NO resolution.

not_P.title: Will IBM not lay off at least 1,800 employees by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, IBM has not confirmed the layoff of at least 1,800 employees as part of its AI-focused reorganization plan. Confirmation must not come from official company announcements, regulatory filings, or reports by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The layoffs must not be explicitly linked to the AI-focused reorganization plan announced in 2023. If IBM confirms a higher number of layoffs, or if such confirmation meeting these criteria is made by the resolution date, the question will resolve as NO. Confirmation of layoffs that do not reach the 1,800 employee threshold by the resolution date will also result in a YES resolution.

para_P.title: Will IBM terminate a minimum of 1,800 staff members by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed YES if, by July 31, 2024, IBM has officially acknowledged the termination of at least 1,800 staff members as part of its restructuring strategy focused on artificial intelligence. Such acknowledgment must be derived from formal company communications, regulatory submissions, or reports from no fewer than two credible news outlets (like Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The terminations must be directly associated with the AI-focused restructuring plan that was revealed in 2023. If IBM confirms a lesser number of terminations, or if there is no confirmation that aligns with these stipulations by the resolution date, the inquiry will be deemed NO. Any partial terminations or gradual implementations that do not meet the 1,800 staff member threshold by the resolution date will also lead to a NO outcome.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) Tiff Macklem remains as Governor of the Bank of Canada and (b) IBM lays off fewer than 1,800 employees?

If he is no longer serving as Governor by the resolution date for any reason (including but not limited to resignation, removal, or end of term), the question resolves as NO. (b) IBM has confirmed the layoff of fewer than 1,800 employees as part of its AI-focused reorganization plan, or if no confirmation meeting the criteria for the original question is made by the resolution date. Confirmation of fewer layoffs or lack of confirmation must come from official company announcements, regulatory filings, or reports by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal).
